<!--To help us understand and resolve your issue, please fill out the form to the best of your ability. Feel free to delete the sections that do not apply.-->

**Description of the problem**

<!-- Please be as detailed as you can when describing an issue. The more information we have, the easier it will be for us to track this down. -->

When plotting colorbars in `subplot`s, the font size of colorbar labels cannot be changed by `FONT_ANNOT_PRIMARY` or even `FONT`.

<!-- It helps a lot if you share any data files required to run your script. You can drag-and-drop them here or paste a link to Dropbox/GoogleDrive/etc. -->

```
range=-R0/200/0/100
gmt begin test png
gmt subplot begin 2x1 -Fs6c/4.5c -M0/0c -A+o-0.4c/-0.0c
  gmt subplot set 0 -A'(a)'
  gmt colorbar ${range} -Chot -DjMR+o-0.4c/0+m+ef -I0.3  --FONT_ANNOT_PRIMARY=5p

  gmt subplot set 1 -A'(b)'
  gmt basemap -JX? ${range} -Btblr
  gmt colorbar -Chot -DjMR+o-0.4c/0+m+ef -I0.3  --FONT_ANNOT_PRIMARY=1p

gmt subplot end
gmt end
```

**Full error message**

<!-- Tip: you'll get more detailed error messages if you add -Vd to your gmt commands. -->

It doesn't trigger an error, just not working as expected.

**Actual outcome**
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/28425640/111424510-1edb0100-86af-11eb-9929-98b0f6c69eb7.png)




<!--The output produced by the above script, which may be a screenshot, console output, etc.-->

**Expected outcome**
Setting to something like `1p` should generate small texts. Also, whether `basemap` exists or not should not change the behavior (In this case, when no `basemap` or anything else creating a frame, the parameter `FONT_ANNOT_PRIMARY` does show effect)

However, just reversing the order of these two subplots makes it different:
```
range=-R0/200/0/100
gmt begin test png
gmt subplot begin 2x1 -Fs3c/2c -M0/0c -A+o-0.4c/-0.0c
  gmt subplot set 0 -A'(a)'
  gmt basemap -JX? ${range} -Btblr
  gmt colorbar -Chot -DjMR+o-0.4c/0+m+ef -I0.3  --FONT_ANNOT_PRIMARY=1p

  gmt subplot set 1 -A'(b)'
  gmt colorbar ${range} -Chot -DjMR+o-0.4c/0+m+ef -I0.3  --FONT_ANNOT_PRIMARY=5p

gmt subplot end
gmt end
```
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/28425640/111425024-c5270680-86af-11eb-89ab-084c494a3ac3.png)

Furthermore, this function works fine in GMT 6.1.1.

<!--A description of the expected outcome from the above script.-->

**System information**

* Operating system:
MacOS Mojave
* GMT version (`gmt --version`)
6.2.0_16e81ff_2021.03.16

👋 Thanks for opening your first issue here! Please make sure you filled out the template with as much detail as possible. We appreciate that you took the time to contribute!

Please make sure you read our [Contributing Guide](https://github.com/GenericMappingTools/gmt/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md) and abide by our [Code of Conduct](https://github.com/GenericMappingTools/gmt/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md).

> @meghanrjones, looks like the auto-scaling happens here even if --FONT_ANNOT_PRIMARY=5p is set:
> 
> `colorbar [DEBUG]: Computed primary annotation font size: 7.76267 p Dimension scaling: 0.776267`
> 
> suggesting the nominal font size is 10p prior to the size scaling.

Yes, I will debug to figure out why that is happening.

@PaulWessel, the problem is that ``parse`` calls ``gmt_auto_offsets_for_colorbar`` which, if there's a session file with frame attributes, calls ``gmtinit_conf_modern_override``, which resets anything set by ``GMT_Parse_Common``

Here's the relevant lines from the start of psscale.c:
```
	if (GMT_Parse_Common (API, THIS_MODULE_OPTIONS, options)) Return (API->error);
	Ctrl = New_Ctrl (GMT);	/* Allocate and initialize a new control structure */
	if ((error = parse (GMT, Ctrl, options)) != 0) Return (error);
```

I think any GMT defaults set during the session should not be reset, for example this should have a 20p colorbar primary annotation:

```
gmt begin test_font
gmt set FONT_ANNOT_PRIMARY 20p
gmt basemap -JX10c -R0/200/0/100 -Bafg -Vd
gmt colorbar -Chot -DjMR+o-0.4c/0+m+ef -I0.3 -Vd
gmt end show
```

Also, just to be clear this is not a exclusively subplot problem, but will happen with any modern-mode auto-positioned colormap:

```
gmt begin test1
gmt basemap -JX10c -R0/200/0/100 -Ba -Vd
gmt colorbar -Chot -DjMR+o-0.4c/0+m+ef -I0.3 --FONT_ANNOT_PRIMARY=20p -Vd
gmt end show
```
What are your thoughts on the resetting of defaults in a session?

> I wonder if we pass _options_ into gmt_auto_offsets_for_colorbar (...) then perhaps after gmtinit_conf_modern_override (GMT) is called at the end of it we can re-process just the **--PAR**=_value_ arguments? That should replace the auto with actual values. I.e., at the very end of _gmt_auto_offsets_for_colorbar_, do something like this
> 
> ```
> void gmt_auto_offsets_for_colorbar (struct GMT_CTRL *GMT, double offset[], int justify, struct GMT_OPTION *options) {
> ...
> 
> for (opt = options; opt; opt = opt->next) {
>   if (opt->option != ' -') continue;   /* Not a parameter setting */
>   c = strchr (opt->arg, '=');
>   c[0] = '\0';  /* Remove = */
>   n_errors += gmtlib_setparameter (GMT, opt->arg, &c[1], false);
> }
> ```

That wouldn't fix this case (do you think the FONT_ANNOT_PRIMARY from earlier in the session shouldn't apply to colorbar?):

```
gmt begin test_font
gmt set FONT_ANNOT_PRIMARY 20p
gmt basemap -JX10c -R0/200/0/100 -Bafg -Vd
gmt colorbar -Chot -DjMR+o-0.4c/0+m+ef -I0.3 -Vd
gmt end show
```
Right.  So there may be a gmt.conf that has non-auto settings for fonts, and there may be --PAR-value incoming.  I need coffee and breakfast first I think.

> Right. So there may be a gmt.conf that has non-auto settings for fonts, and there may be --PAR-value incoming. I need coffee and breakfast first I think.

OK, I will try to figure something out in the meantime and will post if any ideas arrive.

I think using ``gmt_reload_settings (GMT)`` rather than ``gmtinit_conf_modern_override (GMT)`` might work. Checking it now.

Edit: does not work.
@hzfmer, your examples should work properly now after PR #4982.

> @hzfmer, your examples should work properly now after PR #4982.

Thank you @MarceloBanik and @PaulWessel  for your impressively quick fix. I used Anaconda to install GMT so I cannot verify how it works now, but I will try it once the conda package is updated.

It looks like a bug that affects many plots. 

@weiji14 Could you please update the conda-forge dev version when you have time?

Sure, I can trigger a new version build. Give me a few minutes.

Edit: done at https://github.com/conda-forge/gmt-feedstock/pull/141. Please review.
@hzfmer, you can now install the latest GMT dev version using `conda install -c conda-forge/label/dev gmt`. That will pull in GMT version `6.2.0.dev12+922af84` which contains the fix at #4982.

> @hzfmer, you can now install the latest GMT dev version using `conda install -c conda-forge/label/dev gmt`. That will pull in GMT version `6.2.0.dev12+922af84` which contains the fix at #4982.

It does work! Thank you all again!
